content.raw:
The problem is that I cannot call *world->GetPhysicsEngine()* in the constructor or in the load() method.
I imagine the world is still not ready.

I've changed the casting from *boost::dynamic_pointer_cast* to *boost::static_pointer_cast* for gaining some performance.
content.html:
The problem is that I cannot call world->GetPhysicsEngine() in the constructor or in the load() method. I imagine the world is still not ready.

I've changed the casting from boost::dynamic_pointer_cast to boost::static_pointer_cast for gaining some performance.

content.raw: Instead of `Load`, you could create the testRay in an `Init` function. That happens after `Load`.
content.html: Instead of Load, you could create the testRay in an Init function. That happens after Load.

content.raw: const variables should start with a capital letter, and be camel-cased. Only enums and #defines are all caps. It seems that these values should be #defined instead of static const.
content.html: const variables should start with a capital letter, and be camel-cased. Only enums and #defines are all caps. It seems that these values should be #defined instead of static const.

content.raw: Use `this->` when referring to class members (this->STEP), which should be (`this->Step`, `this->XLimit`, `this->YLimit`).
content.html: Use this-> when referring to class members (this->STEP), which should be (this->Step, this->XLimit, this->YLimit).

content.raw: Use Gazebo's built in random number generator: `math/Rand.hh`
content.html: Use Gazebo's built in random number generator: math/Rand.hh

content.raw: This loop could go on forever. Consider using a timeout.
content.html: This loop could go on forever. Consider using a timeout.

content.html: Use a timeout to prevent endless loop

content.raw:
Looks like a potential race condition here: a few lines above we subscribe to a topic, registering as a callback `OnNewPropagationGrid()`, which will set `this->ReceivedMsg` to `true`.  Assuming that message handling can happen in parallel with this constructor, then this line will overwrite the assignment of `this->ReceivedMsg`, setting it back to `false`.

To avoid this potential problem (and for simplicity), I suggest initializing class members like `isFirst` and `receivedMsg` in the constructor preamble, instead of here in the body.
content.html:
Looks like a potential race condition here: a few lines above we subscribe to a topic, registering as a callback OnNewPropagationGrid(), which will set this->ReceivedMsg to true. Assuming that message handling can happen in parallel with this constructor, then this line will overwrite the assignment of this->ReceivedMsg, setting it back to false.

To avoid this potential problem (and for simplicity), I suggest initializing class members like isFirst and receivedMsg in the constructor preamble, instead of here in the body.

content.raw:
Some things that Carlos and I noticed in testing:

* The transmitter's data volume is too great for the Topic Visualizer text widget.  If you try to visualize the `/gazebo/default/wirelessTransmitter/link/wirelessTransmitter/transceiver` (or equivalent) topic in the GUI, Gazebo becomes unresponsive (doesn't crash, just gets very slow).
* The shadow cast by an box obstacle in the visualized propagation field looks wrong.  The shadow itself might be the right shape, but it looks like it's in the wrong location.  I'll try to attach a screenshot demonstrating the issue.
* Sometimes, when deleting a transmitter or receiver, Gazebo exits.  It looks like a clean exit, not an uncaught signal or exception.  Not sure what's going on there.
content.html:
Some things that Carlos and I noticed in testing:

  • The transmitter's data volume is too great for the Topic Visualizer text widget. If you try to visualize the /gazebo/default/wirelessTransmitter/link/wirelessTransmitter/transceiver (or equivalent) topic in the GUI, Gazebo becomes unresponsive (doesn't crash, just gets very slow).
  • The shadow cast by an box obstacle in the visualized propagation field looks wrong. The shadow itself might be the right shape, but it looks like it's in the wrong location. I'll try to attach a screenshot demonstrating the issue.
  • Sometimes, when deleting a transmitter or receiver, Gazebo exits. It looks like a clean exit, not an uncaught signal or exception. Not sure what's going on there.
Issue #805 captures the first bullet.

content.raw:
* The transmitter data volume for visualization has been reduced considerably.
* "Shadows" caused by the obstacles fixed. Now the translations/rotations when moving objects are calculated properly.
* Problem deleting the sensors fixed. There was a race condition between the physics engine and the sensor thread when both were trying to release resources (thanks to Nate and Steve for hunt the problem down).
content.html:
• The transmitter data volume for visualization has been reduced considerably.
  • "Shadows" caused by the obstacles fixed. Now the translations/rotations when moving objects are calculated properly.
  • Problem deleting the sensors fixed. There was a race condition between the physics engine and the sensor thread when both were trying to release resources (thanks to Nate and Steve for hunt the problem down).

content.raw:
This test spawns two receivers and one transmitter between them. In addition, it spawns an obstacle between the transmitter and one of the receivers. The goal of the test is to verify that the signal strength is lower in the receiver occluded by the obstacle.

Internally, I use a ray shape to detect if there are objects between transmitter and receiver. Apparently, ode detects the collision but bullet not.
I am going to create some bullet tests to verify that this is the problem.
content.html:
This test spawns two receivers and one transmitter between them. In addition, it spawns an obstacle between the transmitter and one of the receivers. The goal of the test is to verify that the signal strength is lower in the receiver occluded by the obstacle.

Internally, I use a ray shape to detect if there are objects between transmitter and receiver. Apparently, ode detects the collision but bullet not. I am going to create some bullet tests to verify that this is the problem.
